content:
Hey, is there a theorem about the circumference of a circle, or the surface area of an n-dimensional sphere? I only found volume formulas (including circle area), and Measure.toSphere which I'm not sure is related.
Thanks!
Can you state the theorem you're asking about?

In English:
For every natural n, define the n dimensional sphere $S_n$ to be the collection of of points in (n+1) euclidean space whose distance from the origin equals 1. Then the surface integral of 1 over $S_n$ equals:
$2*pi^{(n+1)/2}/Gamma((n+1)/2)$

Not sure how to state it in Lean since I couldn't find a definition for surface integrals
I would argue (as @Eric Wieser and I were discussing) that Hausdorff measure is the correct way to state it, but unfortunately we don't seem to know much about the 2-measure on R^3 yet...
but I assume if you want to state it in terms of integrals, you'd project the northern hemisphere to the unit disc in R^2, and then just write a double integral inside the unit disc?
(discussing in person, to save anyone looking for the Zulip thread)
I do want to know that it is the "correct" thing, but I have no idea how any of the formality works

If we don't have surface integral, then a cheat way is to consider the volume of a sphere shell divide by the thickness of it, then take the limit as thickness tends to zero.

To define surface integral I think we should need integral of differential forms.
so basically the derivative of the volume with respect to the radius?
that looks like a one line proof XD

Kenny Lau said:

so basically the derivative of the volume with respect to the radius?

At least it's correct for 2D and 3D case :joy:

Jz Pan said:

Kenny Lau said:

so basically the derivative of the volume with respect to the radius?

At least it's correct for 2D and 3D case :joy:

Why would it be wrong?
Volume for "1D" ball is 2 * r, so circumference of a "0D" circle is 2 :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
Zero-dimensional Hausdorff measure of two points is 2 :)

Note that our definition of Hausdorff measure is not correctly normalized for the Euclidean metric, so to use it you need to scale it by an appropriate normalization factor. (Either scale n-dimensional Hausdorff measure by the inverse of the n-dimensional Hausdorff measure of a set you want to have measure 1, which means you don't need to prove what the measure of that set actually is with the current normalization, only that it's nonzero, or scale by an expression involving the gamma function, and then past discussions suggest you'd need to prove the isodiametric inequality to show that really does give the desired normalization.)

Joseph Myers said:

Note that our definition of Hausdorff measure is not correctly normalized for the Euclidean metric, so to use it you need to scale it by an appropriate normalization factor. (Either scale n-dimensional Hausdorff measure by the inverse of the n-dimensional Hausdorff measure of a set you want to have measure 1, which means you don't need to prove what the measure of that set actually is with the current normalization, only that it's nonzero, or scale by an expression involving the gamma function, and then past discussions suggest you'd need to prove the isodiametric inequality to show that really does give the desired normalization.)

What's wrong with the normalization?

#mathlib4 > Hausdorff measure normalisation @ üí¨

There are different conventions about how to normalize Hausdorff measure. The one used in mathlib doesn't produce the same results as Lebesgue measure in two or more dimensions.
@Aaron Liu what's the correct standard 2.5-dimensional object and its correct volume?

Joseph Myers said:

#mathlib4 > Hausdorff measure normalisation @ üí¨

There are different conventions about how to normalize Hausdorff measure. The one used in mathlib doesn't produce the same results as Lebesgue measure in two or more dimensions.

I haven't really followed the thread but I would assume that if n is an integer then [0,1]^n should have volume 1?

Kenny Lau said:

Aaron Liu what's the correct standard 2.5-dimensional object and its correct volume?

ok I understand the problems now

[0,1]^n should have volume 1, yes. We have a theorem that its Hausdorff measure is 1 in the product space with the sup metric. It seems that, with our definition, changing to the Euclidean metric scales the measure by a factor involving the volume of the unit ball.
(More specifically, volume of unit ball / 2^n, where the two factors cancel out in the 1-dimensional case.)
what's stopping us from dividing instead by the volume of the unit cube?

Dividing by the volume (Hausdorff measure with current normalization, that is) of the unit cube is indeed the simple way of getting the right normalization, as long as you only care about integer dimensions.

Joseph Myers said:

#mathlib4 > Hausdorff measure normalisation @ üí¨

There are different conventions about how to normalize Hausdorff measure. The one used in mathlib doesn't produce the same results as Lebesgue measure in two or more dimensions.

But there's a theorem that says it does
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Measure/Hausdorff.html#MeasureTheory.hausdorffMeasure_pi_real

Snir said:

Joseph Myers said:

#mathlib4 > Hausdorff measure normalisation @ üí¨

There are different conventions about how to normalize Hausdorff measure. The one used in mathlib doesn't produce the same results as Lebesgue measure in two or more dimensions.

But there's a theorem that says it does
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Measure/Hausdorff.html#MeasureTheory.hausdorffMeasure_pi_real

That's the theorem I referred to above about the product space with the sup metric. Changing the metric to the Euclidean metric changes the Hausdorff measure.

I think we should add a definition to mathlib of Hausdorff measure scaled appropriately for the Euclidean metric (whatever setup we use to define the scaling) and then we can start proving theorems using it.
I say that the Cantor set is the standard (log(2)/log(3))-dimensional test object and should get measure 1.
There are already proofs for volumes of balls in euclidean space, so we can normalize with unit balls

Normalizing via an expression involving the gamma function for the volume of a unit ball gives you something vaguely meaningful in fractional dimensions. But you need the isodiametric inequality to show that volume of unit ball / 2^n is the correct scale factor so that scaling that way gives the unit cube volume 1.

Joseph Myers said:

I think we should add a definition to mathlib of Hausdorff measure scaled appropriately for the Euclidean metric (whatever setup we use to define the scaling) and then we can start proving theorems using it.

So the default metric on ‚Ñù‚Åø in mathlib isn't the euclidean metric? Do you know why?
The metric on product spaces, in general, is the sup metric. Hausdorff measure is defined in terms of the metric, so changing to a different metric changes the Hausdorff measure.

Snir said:

Joseph Myers said:

I think we should add a definition to mathlib of Hausdorff measure scaled appropriately for the Euclidean metric (whatever setup we use to define the scaling) and then we can start proving theorems using it.

So the default metric on ‚Ñù‚Åø in mathlib isn't the euclidean metric? Do you know why?

No. It is a pitfall documented in https://leanprover-community.github.io/extras/pitfalls.html#distance-in-fin-n--%E2%84%9D recently
I would like to link this thread to #maths > Roadmap to high school geometry . (As in, if you're in this thread, please check out the other thread.)
In the other thread I have code to produce the "correct" measure for R x R which hopefully should be generalisable to R^n...
basically using Basis.addHaar
Hopefully this would work for EuclideanSpace or WithLp?

Kenny Lau said:

In the other thread I have code to produce the "correct" measure for R x R which hopefully should be generalisable to R^n...

I don't see why volume gives the wrong measure on R x R or on R^2, in both cases it looks to me like it has the most sensible normalisation:

import Mathlib

open MeasureTheory Measure

example : volume (Set.Icc (0 : Fin 2 ‚Üí ‚Ñù) 1) = 1 := by
  simp [Real.volume_Icc_pi]

example : volume (Set.Icc (0 : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù) 1) = 1 := by
  rw [volume_eq_prod, Set.Icc_prod_eq, prod_prod]
  simp
volume should already be fine in both product spaces and Euclidean spaces.
@Bhavik Mehta volume is not the problem, Hausdorff measure is the problem
(There is the question however of whether a volume instance should somehow be associated more generally with any affine space for a finite-dimensional real inner product space.)

Kenny Lau said:

Bhavik Mehta volume is not the problem, Hausdorff measure is the problem

Ah, I thought you were claiming that both were the problem!
I didn't know anything 6 hours ago
It's a bit annoying to switch between two threads, can I propose that any further message be sent to #maths > Roadmap to high school geometry

Kenny Lau said:

It's a bit annoying to switch between two threads, can I propose that any further message be sent to #maths > Roadmap to high school geometry

Sounds like the conclusion to this thread is no, there is no code for it. So I'll mark this thread as resolved and move to that new thread
Snir has marked this topic as resolved.
